dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Fourteen years later, after The Babe was gone, there was another guy who had something to do with the legend getting made too. A guy who set a record that summer that was so awesome, some people still don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLS TAKES OFF, STEALING 3RD
dialogues.text: so fast that no one knows he's gone. The Pitcher fires to rd. The 3rd BASEMAN gloves the dirt. The UMPIRE wings the air.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: Safe! WILLS' CLEAT becomes THE P.F. FLYER SNEAKER of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...BENNY RODRIGUEZ, as he steps up to the plate.

dialogues.speaker: THE PITCHER
dialogues.text: fires.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: cranks one deep to right. He tears around the bases like lightning (this kid is real fast). He rounds 3rd. The bal comes in home - cutting him off. He's caught in a pickle.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE CHAIN-LINK BACKSTOP
dialogues.text: YEAH-YEAH, HAM, DeNUNEZ, REPEAT, TIMMY, BERTRAM and SQUIN come unglued and crowd the basepath.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: pickles the CATCHER and 3RD BASEMAN. He feints n' rubba-l  "zooka them out of position. He sprints for home. Safe! Just as he crosses home plate

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: pulls his transistor radio ear plug out.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: Thirty-one! Maury Wills just stole number thirty-one!

dialogues.speaker: THE ON-FIELD TEAM
dialogues.text: throws their gloves 9 different ways in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER TEAM
dialogues.text: (ABOUT BENNY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap! Can't beat that guy! Ya dufuses, why'd ya get him in a pickle for?! Ya know he's the damn pickle king! Rubba legs for sure! Truly rubba legs.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY JOINS THE GANG
dialogues.text: They imitate the big leaguers; skinning five, spittin' chaw-juice. Yeah-Yeah hands Benny his glove. Squints jots the stats in his pee-chee folder.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: Game over. Sixteen zip. Murderers’ Row remains undefeated.

dialogues.speaker: OPPONENT
dialogues.text: Hey! We never got our ups! The lunch bell RINGS. The gang heads across the playgroun back to the bungalows.

dialogues.speaker: OPPONENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All your moms wear boxers! Without looking back, eight "birds" hit the air. Nervous,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of has been watching nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Ham, Squints and Benny go for the 3 spigots, Yeah Yeah taps each rapidfire:

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: Milk-milk-pee.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Great, I'm dyin' a thirst and you pee me out!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Ham, it ain't really.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Then switch with me.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Do I look stupid? Everyone drinks from the 2 "un-cursed" spigots. Ham last. As they turn to leave, Scotty goes for the fountain. The guys hang - waiting for doom. Scotty drinks from the pee spigot! The guys GAG and FAUX-BARF. Scotty has no idea wh they're laughing at him.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: I moved to the neighborhood about a month before school let out. I was from another state, and didn't have a single friend in a thousand miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benny, Ham, Scotty (sitting by himself) and the other are clock watching. The BELL RINGS. Summer vacation! The classroom empties... papers circle to the floor from 35 departing cyclones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Streams of excited KIDS spill into the corridors - a rive scrambling tennis shoes and clashing lunch boxes at the entrance gate.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY'S
dialogues.text: books Monster." caught in the mayhem.

dialogues.speaker: HE SPIES
dialogues.text: the 8 guys forging ahead. He follows them.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: It was a lousy way to end up the 5th grade, 'cause I had zip time to make friends before summer. And that's about where it all started...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty sneaks close around some dense bushes, clutching and "John Glenn - Freedom 7" lunchbox. He steps through t barrier (a secret doorway in the fence) onto the distant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang's homemade baseball diamond. They're:

dialogues.speaker: CLEANING THE BLEACHERS
dialogues.text: with broken brooms.

dialogues.speaker: RAKING THE INFIELD
dialogues.text: with halves of tools.

dialogues.speaker: LAYING NEW CHALK LINES
dialogues.text: with a holed box of detergent powder.

dialogues.speaker: CLEARING THE OUTFIELD
dialogues.text: of leaves, trash and sticks.

dialogues.speaker: RE-ERECTING A PIECE OF RAGGED PLYWOOD
dialogues.text: in left field - painted green and lettered "The Green  panels

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: maintains cover and

dialogues.speaker: PERUSES THE LAYOUT
dialogues.text: a row of houses, whose backyards are all chain link fence The fencing is trimmed individually in wood, bamboo etc.. One has the world's coolest treehouse. Next to it... is t last house. This owner has cordoned his backyard - tall of that green "tropical-look" privacy fiberglass lashed t the fence.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: remains undercover, but he's bustin' to join in.

dialogues.speaker: THE GANG
dialogues.text: never notices him. As they work:

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Fifth grade's history, man. A hundred days, man. A Hundred days of baseball. All Day, everyday, as much as we can. That's the best.

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: We got all summer.

dialogues.speaker: REPEAT
dialogues.text: We got all summer.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Let's play.

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: Yeah-Yeah... let's play. The guys round up in the infield. As they play catch, the spread farther and farther apart... until they've each ta up the position they most like to play. They fit the palt little diamond; scrappy, happy kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tract homes - everybody's got a different thing going in front yard. The guys (sans Timmons') split up toward thei homes - slappin' gloves, "so-longing" for the night.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Everyone but the Timmons twins lived on my new block.

dialogues.speaker: FROM HIS DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: Scotty, shuttling moving boxes to his garage, watches the go.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They lived in a house by the sandlot and had the world's greatest tree house, because their dad was a contractor.

dialogues.speaker: FROM BENNY'S PORCH
dialogues.text: Benny is the last to go in. He sees Scotty watching. So, nods... just a little.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLOCK
dialogues.text: clears to empty. The street lamps arc on, drawing soft wh circles on the sidewalks. FROM THIS HEIGHT, they look lik baseballs dotting the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even before I knew any of them I envied that tree house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shrine to the pastime. Pennants, magazine pictures, gam programs, baseball cards, a whole section of Maury Wills, radiating from a picture of Wills caught in a pickle.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: ...later, it would become second only to Cape Canaveral as a command post  Erector table, for history. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I moved in that summer, I'd never played baseball, but it wasn't too tough figuring out who these guys' heroes were. So, after a week of watching... I figured baseball seemed like the best way to get in with them.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY 'S
dialogues.text: in bed, oiling his glove, staring out his window at Scott house. Taped to his footboard is the most important pictu of all... a picture of The Babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jr. Chemistry set. Heath Kit gadgets. An unbelievable Set contraption with little motors and stuff. An autograp picture of Mr. Wizard. Scotty's pj'd at his erector set bothered and unhappy. This stuff is too damn easy for him He whips on a last bolt and connects the itty-bitty motor

dialogues.speaker: THE CONTRAPTION
dialogues.text: a tiny scoopelvator snatches up a white marble. Drops it a roller coaster track. The marble whips around corners a loop-da-loops... lands in a mini-catapult. Another motor draws it back via a winding string. Boy Scout camping-kni scissors ratchet in - snip the string - the catapult fire

dialogues.speaker: THE MARBLE
dialogues.text: leaps a little green fence and WONK! Ouuuhhh! beans

dialogues.speaker: HIS MOTHER, (HAVING JUST COME IN)
dialogues.text: right in the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Scotty winces at the shot.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I thought we agreed we'd take this apart... and not spend so much time in here.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: (FEELING LOW)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know - but it's just nighttime.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Scotty, have you made any friends yet?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Why not, honey?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: "Cause I'm still "new."

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Honey, I don't want you sitting in here all summer fiddling with this stuff, like you did last summer... and the one before that. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty, look at me. I know you're smart, and I'm proud of you. But you have to get outside, you have to... play. She sits across from him, trying to get through. 10

dialogues.speaker: MOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to get out in the fresh air and make friends. Run around and scrape your knees. Get dirty. Climb trees  and hop fences. Get in trouble for crying out loud. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too much, but some. You have my permission. Now how many mothers do you think say that to their sons?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: None mothers I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I want you to make friends this summer Scotty. Lots of them.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: I know, but I don't - I'm no good at anything. Face it, Mom, I'm just an

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: - and you'll always be just an egghead with an attitude like that. So promise me, alright?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: "Kay.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Maybe tomorrow you'll make some friends.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe tomorrow. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom? Do you think Bill - I mean Dad - will teach me to play catch?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Are you kidding, he'd love it, you know what an athlete he wasIn high school. (ALTERMNATE LINE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what a pitcher he was in high college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty slurps a glass of chocolate Quick. Rinses the glas too carefully. Gathers courage for something. Breathes de starts across the house. 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty peeks through a slightly open door. BILL moves aro inside, unpacking boxes. Scotty reaches to knock. Stops. Almost walks away. Then musters the gumption. KNOCKS.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah... Scotty takes a few cautious steps into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a trophy room. Ribbons, plaques, trophies. Bill must'v been some athlete; but he limps now. Scotty lingers... gathering more courage.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: My real dad died when I was just a little kid. My mom married Bill a year before we moved to the neighborhood. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the time, he and I were still getting used to each other.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Um, Dad - sorry, I mean Bill, remember you promised you'd teach me to play catch?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Um hum... He dusts a batting trophy.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Well, could you teach me?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Sure. He places a pitching plaque. Scotty waits awkwardly. Wait for more words. They don't come.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Okay. Great. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Um hum. Scotty leaves, bringing the door with him on his way out. Through the cracked portal he sees Bill set a silver pedestal on the main shelf. On this he sets a baseball... 12 just a baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty wakes up. Checks his (Theme) clock. 8:30. He bolts out of bed. Dashes through the house to the front door. Throws it open and runs down to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the sidewalk. Fan sprinklers water all the lawns. Way far down the block

dialogues.speaker: HE GLIMPSES
dialogues.text: Ham, at the HELMS BAKERY TRUCK, buying a donut, then scrambling around the far corner.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Hey-hey, come on! Wait up - wait up!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: panics. Runs back inside and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...strips off his cowboy pj's. Redresses. Digs through hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: finding a vinyl, "toy" baseball glove. It's still in the package, with a note attached: "To Scotty Boy - Love, Grandma!" It's all he's got. He shovels through a pair of Mickey Mo ears - a cowboy hat - finds the closest thing he's got to baseball cap... a long, duck-billed fishing cap with a bi embroidered trout.  emerging sandlot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty runs by (soon familiar places):

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE LEAGUE FIELD,
dialogues.text: where he slows momentarily, envious of the crisply unifor kids... wow. Moving on down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: whose backyards we already know. Scotty flat out stops at 13

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: with the fiberglass panels out back. Scary place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty slips quietly through the secret fence doorway,

dialogues.speaker: DEEP LEFT FIELD
dialogues.text: where he hugs the perimeter, moving slowly toward the common houses. Winded, Scotty finds

dialogues.speaker: THE GANG'S
dialogues.text: already playing "over the line."

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: They never kept score. They never chose sides. They never even really stopped playing the game... it just went on forever. Everyday they picked up right where they left off the day before. It was an endless "dream game." (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was only 8 of them, so they didn't have a whole team. It didn't matter though... Benny was so good he took everyone's position when it was there ups. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know any of that then... I just knew they were having the time of their lives and I wanted to be a part of it.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: watches and listens (as he goes) to the SHARP, satisfying sound of the hardball, SNAPPING CLEANLY in the oily leath of their gloves.

dialogues.speaker: HE LOOKS AT
dialogues.text: his own toy glove... how embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: continues around the perimeter, trying to be seen and bec invisible. He goes unwittingly CLOSER TO those green fiberglass panels. 14

dialogues.speaker: DENUNEZ
dialogues.text: winds up and pitches to

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: who connects big. CRACK!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY'S
dialogues.text: come too close to the green fence. Something has overcome him... fear! He stares with serious woollies at

dialogues.speaker: A HOLE IN THE FIBERGLASS
dialogues.text: and sees only dust rising in time with some great, SOUNDS EXHALATION. And then, before he can draw any conclusions. disaster.

dialogues.speaker: GANG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey! Look out!  ducks... of

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: whips a look up and sees

dialogues.speaker: THE FLY BALL
dialogues.text: coming right at him.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: tracks it, frozen stiff. Scared shitless. At the past possible moment, he throws his arms over his face and social suicide.

dialogues.speaker: THE BALL
dialogues.text: beans him at the glove covering his noggin.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: hits his butt. The ball rolls a bit. Comes to an "I-dare- you" stop: right up against the diseased fiberglass panel that preternatural fence. Scotty pulls his arms away from his face.

dialogues.speaker: THE GANG
dialogues.text: LAUGHS uproariously.

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: Nice catch! 15

dialogues.speaker: REPEAT
dialogues.text: Nice catch!

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Hey! Throw the ball back!

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: Yeah-yeah, hurry up!

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAM
dialogues.text: We gotta a game here, man!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: moves for the ball. As he goes, he sweats:

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: "Kay, I'll get it! (TO HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a goofus - don't be a goofus - don't be a goofus. He reaches the fence and the ball and stops. It's hard to move. The force emanating from the backyard has got him:

dialogues.speaker: DUST THROUGH THE HOLE IN THE FIBERGLASS
dialogues.text: keeps perfect time with the monster-breathing.

dialogues.speaker: AN OLENADER BUSH
dialogues.text: moves. It scares the living kapok out of

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: who snatches up the ball and back-pedals 10 feet.

dialogues.speaker: WE'RE WAITING...
dialogues.text: He throws back the ball. And his chances of getting in wi these guys are over. Because Scotty... throws like a girl

dialogues.speaker: THE BALL
dialogues.text: droops forward in the air. Lands 6 feet from him. Rolls slowly up to the gang, finally coming to a dainty stop at DeNunez' feet.

dialogues.speaker: THE GANG
dialogues.text: looks from the ball to Scotty... they CRACK UP! 16

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: walks away... crying.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: (TO HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life is over.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: is the only one that isn't laughing. He stares the others down.

dialogues.speaker: DENUNEZ
dialogues.text: Come on, Benny-man, didn't you see that throw? He imitates it, "flipping" his glove to Ham. The gang BUS UP again.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: (TRULY STUNNED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kid's got the gaw'damn panty- waistiest arm I ever saw in my whole life.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: I seen a guy once that threw like that. I mean not that bad, but at least so bad that he hadda move in the fourth grade 'cause they nicknamed him "Bloomers." Benny's look stifles the bunch.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: I bet not one of you knows how The Babe got his nickname.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Easy, 'cause of the way he looked like a little kid face.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAM
dialogues.text: Bull, it's just 'cause he liked kids and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: Wrong. The Babe was called The Babe, because he was like the child of Yankee Stadium.  17

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: I knew it. You're all full of crap. George Herman Ruth got his nickname because his mom died when he was just a little kid, and he hadda go live in an orphanage. Silence. None of the other guys has heard this before.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nobody liked him there. The bigger guys picked on him all the time. And when they messed with him he couldn't fight back, 'cause he was just... like scared. So when they messed with him, he cried about it. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cried... so they called him The Babe. This hits home real good.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How ya think that kid just felt? Benny exits the sandlot, leaving the others with a lesson learned.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Everyone knew Benny was different. Nobody ever voted or anything, but he was the leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Benny goes into his house, the other's round the corne far behind him.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOON
dialogues.text: is up. Full. Like a big baseball.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Even though he seemed like a regular guy, he wasn't. Benny was special, and he was loyal. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pickle. Scotty When they'd all tried out for youth league, they'd all made it. But when they found out they'd have to play on different teams, Benny told 'em that if they couldn't play together, they shouldn't play at all. So, they stayed together. 18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benny's at the window, clutching a baseball, staring over Scotty's house.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: So, the only person that ever felt sorry for me 'cause I was such a weenie was Benjamin Franklin Rodriguez. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though neither of us knew it at the time, we were connected. Like I had been born for just that one moment when I would perform the world's all- time boner, and Benny would bail me out. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connected as friends... born to meet for just that one moment. We DRIFT OFF Benny to his PICTURE OF MAURY WILLS in a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PICTURE OF MAURY WILLS on a Post Super Sugar Crisp box.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: at the table. Bill sifting through mounds of paperwork. eating breakfast. Scotty's spoon CLANGS one too many time Bill looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Sorry... Scotty picks up his bowl and cereal, goes into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where his mom is making coffee.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (QUIETLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?...

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: He's too busy, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (ENCOURAGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back in there and ask. He'll take the time. Go on. 19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty comes back in. Stops mutely near Bill. Long, agonizing seconds pass. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Um, Da - Quick look toward the kitchen, then:

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (so Mom won't hear) - I mean, Bill. Could we... I mean could you, like you said - teach me to catch today?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Um, yeah, but later, okay? I gotta get this done. It ain't much, but it's something.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Okay, thanks. Mom comes in behind Scotty.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Bill, can't you take a break and teach him now?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Mom, it's okay - (NOBODY'S LISTENING)

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Honey, I said I would and I will. I'm just under the gun here, ya know?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Mom, really -

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: - How long could it take? You can't spare a half hour to show him? Bill drops his pen. Checks his watch. A lost battle here.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (ANNOYED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Alright. I'll get my glove. Come on. 20 Bill exits past them. Scotty's been "Mom-embarrassed." Sh looks at him:

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (CLUELESS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. See. Told you so. Scotty shuffles out back, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill slides his hand into his glove. He warms up the crad POPPING the "hardball" into the palm.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: stands ready to "learn" on the other side of the yard. Appropriately pitiful in "trout" cap and toy glove.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Keep your eye on the ball. Put the  glove up where it goes. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, I think so. Bill throws one to Scotty. The toy glove goes up to the right. The ball sails by to the left.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Darn. Sorry. Bill's a little amazed at that one. He checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That's alright, just throw it back. Scotty eagerly retrieves it. Turns to throw - deja vu - h runs over, hands Bill the ball.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Here. He runs back across the yard. Turns 'round again. Holds h glove up stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm ready. Bill cannot believe this. Checks his watch again. 21

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Keep your eye on the ball. Put the glove up where the ball goes. He throws again. The ball bounces off the toy glove - bre the webbing.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Darn. My glove got -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: - not bad. Right side at least. Now, just throw it back this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my glove - Bill's looking at his watch again. Scotty fetches the bal gulps - "flips" it back.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (DISBELIEF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benny comes out of his house. From the sidewalk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: up the side of Scotty's house into the backyard. He can s Scotty. Only Scotty. Standing there game as hell, trying catch balls that seem to be coming too fast. The ball com Scotty ducks. The ball hits the block wall behind him, caroming back toward where we assume Bill is throwing fro

dialogues.speaker: BENNY 'S
dialogues.text: drawing the wrong conclusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty's still game. Bill's at ropes end. Check his watch again.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Alright, Scott, listen, this one's gonna come right at you, easy, okay?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: "Kay. 22

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Just keep your eye on the ball and put your glove up. You'll catch it.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Okay.  through

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: throws.

dialogues.speaker: THE BALL
dialogues.text: comes slowly forward.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: sticks his glove up.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY'S EYES
dialogues.text: widen.

dialogues.speaker: THE BALL
dialogues.text: hits dead center glove. Rips the "toy" webbing. Flies

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: right in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Oh my —

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: - God, whadda jerk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty's mom comes unglued.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Bill! What happened?!

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Well, he - 23  raises

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: (PRIDE'S SAKE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - just took my eye off the ball, Mom. Scotty's mom pulls his hand away from his eye. Great shin Bill grabs a steak from the fridge, FLOPS it over Scotty' eye.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: There. Keep that on for an hour. It'll still be black, but it won't swell. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. We'll try again soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty emerges. Sits on the porch. Pitiful and forlorn. Chin in his hands, he looks across the street. He starts. His hand moves to cover his black eye... but he thinks th better of it.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY 'S
dialogues.text: on the curb across the street. A moment goes by. Benny a hand.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: slowly waves back.

dialogues.speaker: BOTH
dialogues.text: Benny comes over to Scotty's sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Gonna go play some ball. Need a extra guy. Wanna go?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Naw. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Why not? Doncha like baseball?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. But, ah...

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: But what?  Scotty searches for a quick way out of this. Gets it: 24

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: But my glove's busted. So, ya know, I can't go. Thanks, though. Benny reaches behind his back. Takes something out of his jeans - like he's going for a gun. Smiles a little.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: That's okay. He offers it to Scotty... a "real" glove.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got a extra one. Scotty SHOUTS over his shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Mom! I'm gonna go play some ball! As they move away down the block.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. Cool glove.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cool shiner. We gotta stop by the 5 & 10 first. Need a new ball. And chaw and stuff, ya know?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: You dip chaw?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: (COMPLETELY CLUELESS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. A'course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benny & Scotty go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benny grabs a new baseball on the stride, and handful of bazooka from a jar on the soda fountain counter. He leave the money and exits. Scotty follows. 25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benny and Scotty come upon the gang (all their mouths are full a' bazooka) as Ham's chompin' on a candy cigar doing

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Hey! Check me out! I'm the Great Bambino! The gang laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: (OVER EAGER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that? The gang stifles. They're none-to-pleased. Ham sees why. The new kid... "flipper." Eight pairs of eyes burn holes his little soul.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: What?... (BEYOND HIM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAM
dialogues.text: Were you born in a barn, man?

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: Yeah-yeah, what planet are you from?

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: You never heard of The Sultan of Swat?

dialogues.speaker: DENUNEZ
dialogues.text: The Titan of Terror!

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: The Colossus of Clout!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colossus of Clout!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (even he's amazed) The King of Krash!

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: I had no idea who they were talking about. But there was no way I could let them know that... so, I lied. 26

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Oh! The Great Bambino! Of course. I thought you said The Great Bambi.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: (SHIVERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wimpy deer?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Ah, yeah - I guess. Sorry. The gang goes SILENT. They spit - they're tough. Scotty dribbles - he's wimpy.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (W/MOUHTFUL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Scott, this is Ken DeNunez; Alan McClennan, we call him Yeah-Yeah; Hamilton Porter, we call him Ham; Tommy and Timmy Timmons, Bertram Grover Weeks, and Mike "Squints" Palledorus. (TO GANG)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's Scott Smalls.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Hi. The gang just stares.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: He's gonna play with us. He makes nine. Now we got a team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pack follows Benny onto the diamond. Scotty trails a them.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAM
dialogues.text: Why'd you bring him for, Benny?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: "Cause there's eight of us, and he makes nine.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, so would my sister, but I didn't bring her!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: With nine Guys we got a whole team. 27

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: No, with Elswenger we had a whole team, and Elswenger could throw!

dialogues.speaker: DENUNEZ
dialogues.text: He ain't game, Benny. He can't throw for nothin'. Scotty drifts off by himself. He can hear what's exchange

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: Benny, you already play all the empty positions since Elswenger moved to Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: And now I get to rotate 8 positions instead of 7. I need the practice.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: No you don't. It's stupid, Benny. The kid's an L-7 weenie.

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: Yeah-yeah, Oscar Mayer even.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, Squints, and you're Willie  freakin' Mays. You catch like a dork - anybody ever bust your chops about that?

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: (PALTRY EXCUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I'm - ya know, I'm -

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: - and you run like a duck, Yeah- Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: (IT'S TRUE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Kay-'kay... But I'm —

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: - part-a the game.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: (DEFENSIVE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: Yeah-yeah. 28

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: How come he don't get to be? Nobody's got an answer for that one. Base up you blockheads.)

dialogues.speaker: THE GANG
dialogues.text: hits the field. Their suspicious glares aren't lost on

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: standing off by himself, kinda lost. Benny comes over.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You take right field, Smalls.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: (EAGER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Okay. Ah... where exactly is that?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (SURPRISED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, over there. Scotty runs "over there" anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: takes home plate worried: "Maybe the kid is a weenie."

dialogues.speaker: INFIELD
dialogues.text: DeNunez at the mound. Benny's up.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get two. Repeat at 3rd, stabs it effortlessly and fires to 2nd. Ti snatches it down and drag-tags the invisible base runner then fires to Bertram at lst. SNAP! Outta there. Bertram throws back to DeNunez. Benny's ready:

dialogues.speaker: BENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Smalls! Get one!

dialogues.speaker: CRACK
dialogues.text: arcs up... comes down right at

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: who raises the glove, and skippers around, as if he were tracking a falling leaf. The ball lands 5 feet behind him 29

dialogues.speaker: THE GANG
dialogues.text: shakes its collective head, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: runs to the ball, is about to throw... runs it in to DeNu instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Sorry, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: THE GANG
dialogues.text: is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: runs back to right field. Ready again - a game kid.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: trots out after him.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Hey, you can throw it ya know.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: No, I can't... I don't know how. (LUMPY THROAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, thanks for taking me here... but I think better go. Scotty turns to leave. Benny grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: You think too much. I bet you get straight A's and shit, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: No, I got a B once. Actually it was an A minus. (QUICK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it shoulda been a B.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: This is baseball, you're not supposed to think, you're just supposed to play. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever have a paper route?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Uh, I helped a guy one time. 30

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw it like you chuck a paper. When your arm gets here... just let go of it. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let go. Scotty nods. Benny starts back.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Wait - how do I catch it?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Just stand there and stick your glove in the air. I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: HOME PLATE
dialogues.text: Benny mentally calculates the distance. Puts a little rub the ball. Flips it into the air...

dialogues.speaker: BENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Smalls, get one! ...and swings through deliberately. CRACK!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: sees it coming. Stands there stiffly. Sticks his glove up closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Please, catch it. Please, catch it. Please, ca - SNAP! His glove swings down. He opens his eyes. Looks int his glove. The ball is there. He takes it out and chucks the ball like a folded paper.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAM
dialogues.text: catches it good and solid at lst.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAM
dialogues.text: Okay! Hey, let's play ball!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: loosens up. From home plate  Benny 31

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: gives him a "Thumbs Up." The significance of this is only outweighed by his sudden fear, when...

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: glimpses something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of some great, lumbering thing moving past a crack in tho green fiberglass panels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In good spirits, the guys break off to their houses.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: split up in the middle of the street between their homes.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Already at his door, Benny just raises his glove in answe

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait, here - your glove.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty opens a new writing tablet, and titles the page: "Baseball Stuff to Remember." He writes: "1. The Great Bambino?" He hasn't got a clue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benny coaches Scotty. Correct batting stance and swing. thumb-flicks bottle caps at Scotty from a coffee can full They're tough to hit. But soon Scotty's tagging every one them.  THE SUN SETS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DeNunez fires - fastball. CRUNCH! 32

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: tags it. The ball sails over

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS'
dialogues.text: Head in center. From left field

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: gives Scotty another "Thumbs Up." The kid's in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squints arrives with a box of baseball cards.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Everyday, first thing, we'd all pick a card from what we called "The Dugout." Squints shakes it up. Everybody picks one.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was just a shoe box, but whoever we picked, we got to be when it was our ups. One day, when Ham took his pick a little too seriously, the guys let me in on the world's most terrifying secret...

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Bingo! Maury Wills!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Mickey Mou - ah, Mantle.

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: Say hey, Willie Mays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan Musial.

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: Lou Brock.

dialogues.speaker: REPEAT
dialogues.text: Lou Brock - I mean, Luis Aparicio.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAM
dialogues.text: Frank Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: Oh... Bob Uecker. 33

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Hank Aaron. I'm up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang "peppers"

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: (at home plate) mercilessly.

dialogues.speaker: DENUNEZ
dialogues.text: pitches - strike. Pitches again - strike. Delivers and

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: takes a Ruthian cut at it. CONNECTS to deep right.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: tracks it.

dialogues.speaker: THE BALL
dialogues.text: comes down.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: runs beneath it - glove up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: drops into a backyard. The one with the green fiberglass panels.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: stops short. Looks back to

dialogues.speaker: THE GANG
dialogues.text: who're already packing up in slumped dejection.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: makes a decision. Swallows against fear of the fence. He takes one step toward that fence.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Wait a sec, I'll get it! 34

dialogues.speaker: THE GANG
dialogues.text: comes unglued.

dialogues.speaker: NOOOO000000
dialogues.text: They rush over - grab Scotty - pull him back 10 feet into the "Fear-Free" zone.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: Holy crap, you coulda been killed!

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: Yeah-yeah - truly! Whadda you doin'?!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Well, you were all leavin', so I thought I'd just -

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: - if you were thinkin' you wouldn't a thought that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go back there, Smalls.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Then how do we get the ball?

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: We don't.

dialogues.speaker: REPEAT
dialogues.text: We don't.

dialogues.speaker: BERTRAM
dialogues.text: It's gone.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Forever even.

dialogues.speaker: DENUNEZ
dialogues.text: Forget it, it's a memory.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Game's over. We'll get a new one tomorrow. Just forget it. We'll never see it again.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Why not? 35

dialogues.speaker: GANG
dialogues.text: (HUSHED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beast. Scotty stares at them; all heads hung.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Go over there, real slow, and be quiet. Don't touch the fence, just peek through that hole in the green stuff... go on. As Scotty goes forward, the gang steps back.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: craters draws his eye close to the hole in the fence. WE SEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LIMITED VIEW of 3 feet square. WE SEE nothing but the ball... in the small crater it's made in the dirt. There oddly similar craters in the immediate vicinity. Those are empty.

dialogues.speaker: A MAMMOTH, HAIRY PAW
dialogues.text: comes down from out of nowhere. As it CLEARS FRAME, the baseball is gone. Only the crater remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty snaps his head away from the hole - runs over to

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Something got the ball! (UNNERVED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that thing?! Considered looks are exchanged, then, in unison:

dialogues.speaker: GANG
dialogues.text: Campout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aglow. (NOTE: Same as Sc. 80)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Boy Scout lantern. Professionally built structure. The gang's got sleeping bags. They're roasting marshmallows o a Cub Scout camping stove. 36 Ham's brought personal s'mores supplies.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Wanna s'more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some more of what?

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: No. You wanna s'more?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: I haven't had anything yet, so how can I have any more of nothing?

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: You kill me Smalls. Look, these are s'mores stuff. Pay attention: (CONCOCTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First you take the graham - you put the chocolate on the graham, Hershey's of course - you hold the chocolate on the graham while you roast the mallow- He does. The mallow flames to life.

dialogues.speaker: HAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -then when the mallow's flamin', ya stuff it on the chocolate and cover it with the other end. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, you scarf. Ham does. The junk squirts half way down his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: HAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (BARELY INTELLIGIBLE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda messy... Good though. Squints turns the lantern down low...

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: Alright, listen up. (TO SCOTTY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time DeNunez heard this story he

dialogues.speaker: DENUNEZ
dialogues.text: - Bull, Squints!

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: You did, man. DeNunez shuts up. It's true.  to 37

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: When Yeah-Yeah heard it he peed his pants.

dialogues.speaker: YEAH-YEAH
dialogues.text: Shut up, Squints - did not!

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: You did, man.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: And when The Ham heard it he barfed up two bags of marshmallows.

dialogues.speaker: HAM
dialogues.text: Liar! It was only one.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS
dialogues.text: So stay away from the door... you might fall out. And don't sit on your sleeping bag... you could shit your pants. (SOLEMN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, quiet... Absolute silence. Kid-reverence equals fright.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The legend of The Beast goes back a long time... before any of us could pick up a baseball. Back to a place called Mertle's Acres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A legendary place... benefitting from years of kid- embellishment: a gothic, scrapyard fortress oddly designe keep something in not out.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The Beast belongs to Mr. Mertle, the guy that used to own Mertle's Acres  Junkyard. And nobody's ever seen him since the day it happened...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blurbling pockets of super-heated muck. 38

dialogues.speaker: BURNED-OUT SHELLS
dialogues.text: of twisted vehicles - strewn carcasses. A battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: OLD APPLIANCES
dialogues.text: that form tortured faces in the shadowy recesses.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Mertle's Acres was a bitchin' place, that had everything you could ever imagine.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER STUFF
dialogues.text: like savaged shopping carts. A school bus graveyard. Scra motorbikes. Cargo ship buoy balls. The gutted shell of a fighter plane.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And the stuff was worth a fortune. So, one day Mr. Mertle got him this new pup from the pound. They were glad to get rid of him, on account of while he'd been there, he'd killed three dogs bigger than he was. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was exactly what Mr. Mertle figured he needed to protect his junkyard, "cause people kept stealing stuff at night, when he wasn't around.

dialogues.speaker: WE DRIFT THROUGH
dialogues.text: a maze of dark, grimy junk-passageways.

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Beast.) So he bought The Beast, and set him loose in Mertle's Acres.

dialogues.speaker: SOMETHING LOPES BY
dialogues.text: at the end of a passage. (NOTE: We never fully see The

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Beast was still just a pup of six months, but he already weighed a 150 pounds... and he kept gettin' bigger.

dialogues.speaker: A TRASH BAG
dialogues.text: full of meat hits the ground - disappears. SLIFFTHT! It spits back INTO FRAME... empty and tattered. 39

dialogues.speaker: SQUINTS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He threw The Beast a trash bag full of meat every night, and just left him alone. All alone in the whole place by himself... to grow.

dialogues.speaker: AN EYEBALL
dialogues.text: among a pile of broken headlights. As big as the headligh

dialogues.speaker: FLEETING GLIMPSES OF MORE STUFF
dialogues.text: like Mannequins, with bite-chunks missing. Plastic flamingoes, brutally mangled. A decapitated "lawn jockey." A plastic cow, legs gnawed off. And BREATHING... amongst the artificial "life" forms.

dialogues.speaker: A GARGANTUAN FOOTPRINT
dialogues.text: in the center of an old truck tire.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAST'S SHOULDERS
dialogues.text: moving powerfully - as tall as a burned-out VW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, in a few months, the pup grew into The Beast. And he grew big as a car. And he grew mean, 'cause nobody liked him, and he didn't like nobody either. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so he only had one thing on his mind... to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO THIEVES in ski-masks. Suddenly, a HEATED WIND strips their masks. Two elephantine feet come down on their face They SCREAM.

dialogues.text: The green fiberglass panels are brand new here in the pas

dialogues.text: There was only one nightgame a year. On the Fourth of July, the whole sky would brighten up with fireworks, giving us just enough light for a game. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Once we got over trying to be big shots,  we just stuck to what we could handle, and swore off the hard stuff forever. When we finally got back together for some baseball, something amazing happened. (BEAT)

dialogues.text: They tear open their packs of baseball cards. First thing first - they eat the gum sticks. Then, shuffle through th cards looking for gold.

dialogues.text: Imfuckingpossible. (ALTERNATE LINE, same

dialogues.speaker: BENNY

dialogues.text: obeys. They hurry into the field. As they go:

dialogues.text: It's a miracle, Smalls. A damn miracle.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: We all expected something to happen right then... during that game. What we had just witnessed was bordering on the supernatural... we knew that greater hands than ours were at work. (BEAT)

dialogues.text: And it happened alright. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happened right in front of our noses... and we didn't even know it.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GREEN FIBERGLASS FENCE
dialogues.text: Scotty runs right up to it - clutches desperately. Pantin Trembling. The guys arrive. Scotty turns back to them... has aged 25 years.

dialogues.text: No! You don't understand! THAT WASN'T

dialogues.text: eyes go to Scotty.

dialogues.text: Nice knowing -

dialogues.text: Smalls, you mean to tell me you went home and swiped a ball that was signed by Babe Ruth, and brought it out here and actually played with it?

dialogues.text: And actually played with it?! 76

dialogues.text: (that did it)
